captions.text:
- All right, do you. You do you, Tyler.
- Okay.

- Hey guys! It's me, Tyler
Oakley, and I am here
with the one and the only,
Thanks for hanging out with me today.
Before we even begin, I need to tell you

I was actually just in your
house a couple months ago.
- Oh, yeah. I heard you were hanging out

It was amazing, so I felt
like this was meant to be.

- I felt like I needed
my time with Tyler, so...
So we're actually here today to

Let's talk a little bit
about where you come from.
- I grew up in Chicago on the southside,
so I'm a product of public schools.
I went to a magnet high school.

- And I was a good
student, and I had a plan
to go to a good college.

I did what I had to do to
get prepared and got into

- Got my Bachelors in
Sociology and went on

to Harvard Law School and
got my law degree. - Casual.

- And so obviously, for me
education was the key to

all of my success which
is one of the reasons why

Because we want to make
sure kids in this country

understand that you
have to get an education

beyond high school these days.
- Of course.

- It's just not enough to
get your high school diploma

unless you're just like
a superdude like you.
- All right, where did you go to college?

- Now, actually we have
something in common.

We're both first generation college goers.
- Yes, yes.

There's a lot of people at
home that might be similar.

Maybe their family doesn't
expect them to do that,
- I would urge your viewers to go for it

and to not be afraid.
- [Tyler] You do you.

- Yeah, you do you, and
there's no magic to being here.

I know that you understand
that you had to take

You had to seek help where
you found it because I know my

parents, they couldn't really
walk me through the process.

- Yeah, they didn't
have a clue, but I would
urge people to seize the day, you know.
- One of my favorite things that you said

I feel like when I was
thinking about college,
I had no idea what to even ask.

So we're going to play a
little game, if that's okay.

- You do? Okay, good.
- I do.

- So we are gonna take
turns asking each other as

many questions as we
can in one minute each,

- So I will ask a question first.
- Oh, you have a basket.

- Describe your college
experience in one word.
- I was an RA. Three years.

Where could you be found
on a Friday night, Tyler?

- In my dorm babysitting
the kids 'cause I'm an RA.

- Oh yeah, that's right. Well,
what about that fourth year?

- If you could go back
to college, would you?

I feel like now, having
seen more of the world,
I'm like, I wanna study more.
- That's what I try to tell kids.
It's like, college is the ultimate thing
to do when you're that age.

Why would you want to rush
out and work right away?
- You get to do whatever you want.

- All you have to do is
write some papers and
take an exam here or there.

I'm gonna interrogate ya.
- I'm focused.

Proudest moment during
your college experience?
The proudest moment, getting my diploma.
- How often did you visit home?
- You know. Well, because it was Chicago,
At least on the big breaks, so-
Did you ever fail a test?

Now, I got C's, I got some
C's, but I never failed a test.
- So you never failed a class?
- Never failed a class, I'm sorry.
- No no, that's fine. Don't be sorry.
Biggest fear about going to college?
- Ooh. Just could I do it?

There were a lot of
people who were telling me
Princeton's gonna be too hard for you,

you shouldn't try it, and so-
- [Tyler] Look at you now.

- That's what I want kids to know.
- [Tyler] Right.
- If I can do it, me and Tyler can do it,
- We need you to do it.
We need you to be educated.

- Well, I feel like
everyone at home, if there's
one thing that you could tell them.
I'm sure they're eager to hear it.

So if you have a takeaway
message for the people.

- You have to get your
education beyond high school.

If you're gonna compete in
this globalizing economy,

But in this country we
have many ways to do it.

Just ask questions,
don't be afraid to fail.
Failure is the key to success.
- So if you have questions, ask the people
around you, ask the people in your life,
and yeah, you'll make it through.

- Thank you so much for coming.
- That was fun.
- This is fun. You're the best.
- What're all these cameras for, then?

- If you wanna, like,
speak right to the camera.
- If you wanna do that, you may.

comments.text:
No jokes about how Michelle is the man in the relationship, about how every 
time Barack comes home she slaps him with her huge testosterone-driven 
hands and Barack falls to the floor crying, "I'm sorry Michelle, I didn't 
know" *THOWP* *SHUT THE FUCK UP BARACK, YOU KNOW DAMN WELL THAT YOUR BITCH 
ASS* (indecipherable yelling) *COME HOME, BEFORE **9:30** PM OR ELSE SHIT 
HITS THE FUCKING FAN LIKE YOU HITTIN THE FLOOR YOU LITTLE BITCH* (lamps 
being thrown) "I'm so sorry Michelle please don't hit me you're scaring the 
chil-" *THWOP*﻿

comments.text:
Back peddle much @ 1:31; you don't need a college degree if you are 
passionate about what you do. There are many graduates out of work waiting 
tables and high school only graduates making tons of money designing, 
coding, being entrepreneurs, YouTubing (even with college degrees and not 
applying it) and many more. I'm not against specialized knowledge though; 
you should always search for knowledge to better yourself and your craft 
but you don't have to do it through the failed, cookie cutter and out dated 
curriculum offered at colleges; they are in the business of making money 
and the government is now in the business of enslaving the young with debt: 
They make about 70 Billion in profit from student loans in a 5yr time 
frame. ﻿
